S3.T1.caption: Table 1:  State-of-the-art metrics.
references: As shown in Table 1, some state-of-the-art techniques can achieve great results but rely upon previously known ads. Indeed, while the approach of Khemiri et al. [12] stands out and is particularly impressive, it is heavily dependent on finding a discernible pattern of sufficient spectral variations in the spectrogram of known advertisements. This dependency is a significant shared constraint, limiting its applicability, especially when dealing with new or concealed advertising content. The proposed approach capitalizes on both strategies: text-to-speech transcription and text classification utilizing a deep learning transformer model. Therefore, the message and its context play a crucial role.

In summary, comparing the results with those of prior studies in radio advertising detection (as summarised in Table 1), the efficacy of the methodology becomes evident. The resulting model achieves an F1-macro score of 87.7687.7687.76, close to the theoretical maximum of 89.3389.3389.33 that can be achieved with this time resolution, indicating high precision in advertisement detection. For practitioners aiming to harness their models’ highest caliber of performance, employing a training window of 101010 seconds and an inference window of 404040 seconds and rigorously applying the exact segmentation technique in both phases is prudent. The "medium" sized model is also advised.

S6.T2.caption: Table 2:  Dataset split global details.
references: Table 2 shows the data split with the amount of audio used and their advertising time. Table 3 also displays the detailed temporal distribution of the test set, including the date and time slot of the broadcasts. Advertisements from all over the day are represented to avoid any likely bias.

S6.T3.caption: Table 3:  Anonymized test set minor details.
references: Table 2 shows the data split with the amount of audio used and their advertising time. Table 3 also displays the detailed temporal distribution of the test set, including the date and time slot of the broadcasts. Advertisements from all over the day are represented to avoid any likely bias.

S8.T4.caption: Table 4:  Regarding various configurations, this table presents the theoretical baseline values for F1-macro and the average time necessary to transcribe  1 1 1  hour of audio.
references: As mentioned before, the approach presented here will have an inevitable error due to the tagging of the audio-to-text windows and the binary nature of the text classification model’s output. The experiments reveal that the accuracy of identifying advertisements within audio streams is influenced by window length, segmentation technique, and the model size employed for transcription. Table 4 illustrates the trade-off between average transcription times on an Nvidia Tesla V100 with 323232GB of VRAM and the theoretical F1-macro ceiling for every combination of the parameters. Inference times would add up to around 202020 s per audio hour using 888 Inter Core i7 7th Gen cores.

Window Length: We aim to determine if providing more contextual information during training enhances text comprehension and if shorter inference windows can be used without sacrificing performance. According to Table 4, smaller window lengths yield higher theoretical F1-macro scores, indicating more precise segmentation but at the expense of losing context, which can degrade text classification performance.

Besides, instead of shifting the window by its full size for each transcription step, a minor window shift during the sliding window analysis could potentially foster higher asymptotic theoretical maximum F1-macro values in Table 4. Thus, it would involve analyzing progressively smaller new portions of the broadcast, potentially enhancing the precision of advertisement detection for the same window length.

Segmentation Technique: Notably, in Table 4, the model size does not impact the F1-macro score when using the exact technique for the same window size. Results also indicate that the rigorous nature of the exact segmentation consistently yields better results than "non-exact" segmentation. In Figure 8, a more precise segmentation instills a higher fidelity in the transcription process, thus equipping the model with a more robust understanding of the data, albeit at a higher computational cost, according to Table 4. Intriguingly, the second-best performance is achieved by employing the non-exact segmentation technique during training and switching to the "exact" segmentation technique for evaluation, trailing closely behind the scenario where exact segmentation is used for both training and inference. Despite such a slight edge, the probability density accrues predominantly at higher values with a more contained spread in the "exact" segmentation cases than their non-exact counterparts.

S8.T5.caption: Table 5:  F1-macro results when the training window is  10 10 10  s, the inference window is  40 40 40 , the training segmentation is “exact", and the inference segmentation is “exact" to select the best combination of training model size and inference model size
references: Model Size: Lastly, differences among various model sizes are relatively small in Table 5. However, it is noteworthy that the "medium" sized model performs the best, mainly when using the "small" model for inference. Overall, the choice reduces to pick up the best model from Table 5 as a subtable of Figure 9, where the windows and segmentation techniques are fixed as previously stated.
